lines.text: You *were* jealous that your husband was schtupping Yvette. That's why you killed him, too!
Yes. Yes, I did it. I killed Yvette. I hated her, so much...
[stammers]
it-it- the f - it -flam - flames. Flames, on the side of my face, breathing-breathl- heaving breaths. Heaving breaths... Heathing...
Professor Plum, you were once a professor of psychiatry specializing in helping paranoid and homicidal lunatics suffering from delusions of grandeur.
Yes, but now I work for the United Nations.
So your work has not changed.
The game's up, Scarlet. There are no more bullets left in that gun.
Oh, come on, you don't think I'm gonna fall for that old trick?
It's not a trick. There was one shot at Mr. Boddy in the Study; two for the chandelier; two at the Lounge door and one for the singing telegram.
That's not six.
One plus two plus two plus one.
Uh-uh, there was only one shot that got the chandelier. That's one plus two plus *one* plus one.
Even if you were right, that would be one plus one plus two plus one, not one plus *two* plus one plus one.
Okay, fine. One plus two plus one... Shut up! The point is, there is one bullet left in this gun and guess who's gonna get it!
Frankly, Scarlett, I don't give a damn.
Maybe there is life after death.
Life after death is as improbable as sex after marriage!
[last lines]
They all did it. But if you wanna know who killed Mr. Boddy, I did. In the hall. With the revolver. Okay, Chief, take 'em away. I'm gonna go home and sleep with my wife.
Just checking.
Everything all right?
Yep. Two corpses. Everything's fine.
Mrs. White, you've been paying our friend, the blackmailer, ever since your husband died under, shall we say, mysterious circumstances?
Ah!
[laughs]
Why is that funny?
I see! That's why he was lying on his back, in his coffin.
I didn't kill him.
Then why are you paying the blackmailer?
I dont want a scandal, do I? We had had a very humiliating public confrontation. He was deranged. He was
[points to head]
a lunatic! He didn't actually seem to like me very much; he had threatened to kill me in public.
Why would he wanna kill you in public?
I think she meant he threatened, in public, to kill her.
[rolls eyes]
Oh. Was that his final word on the matter?
Being killed is pretty final, wouldn't you say?
And yet, he was the one who died, not you, Mrs. White, not you!
What did he do for a living?
He was a scientist, nuclear physics.
What was he like?

He was always a rather stupidly optimistic man. I mean, I'm afraid it came as a great shock to hime when he died, but, he was found dead at home. His head had been cut off, and so had his, uh... you *know*.
[Colonel Mustard, Professor Plum, and Mr. Green cross legs]
I had been out all evening at the movies.
Do you miss him?
Well, it's a matter of life after death. Now that he's dead, I have a life.
But, he was your second husband. Your first husband also disappeared.
But that was his job. He was an illusionist.
But he never reappeared!

[admittedly]
He wasn't a very good illusionist.
The key is gone!
Never mind about the key, unlock the door!
[smacks Mr.Green on the shoulder]

[grabs Professor Plum by the collar, throttling him]
I CAN'T UNLOCK THE DOOR WITHOUT THE KEY!
[releasing Plum, Mr. Green rattles doorknob]
LET US IN! LET US IN!

[on other side of locked door]
LET US OUT! LET US OUT!
What are you afraid of, a fate worse than death?
No, just death, isn't that enough?
How many husbands have you had?
Mine or other women's?
Yours.
Five.
Five?
soft, strong and disposable.
You lure men to their deaths like a spider with flies.
Flies are where men are most vulnerable.
Right!
So it was you. I was going to expose you.
I know. So I choose to expose myself.
Please, there are ladies present!

[to Miss Scarlet]
So, how did you know Colonel Mustard works in Washington? Is he one of your clients?
Certainly not!
I was asking Miss Scarlet.

[to Miss Scarlet]
Well, you tell him it's not true.
It's not true.

[to Miss Scarlet]
Is that true?
No, it's not true.
Ah ha! So it is true!
A double negative!
A double negative?
[whispering]
You mean you have photographs?
That sounds like a confession to me. In fact the double negative has led to proof positive. I'm afraid you gave yourself away.

[angry, to Wadsworth]
Are you trying to make me look stupid in front of the other guests?
You don't need any help from me, sir.
That's right!
I can explain everything.
You don't have to.
I don't?
Don't worry, there's nothing illegal about any of this.
Are you sure?
Of course, this is America.
I see.
It's a free country, don't you know that?
I didn't know it was *that* free.
It should be just off there.
That must be it!

[they see their destination as lightning splits the sky over Hill House, giving it an ominous cast. The car engine stops]
Why has the car stopped?
It's frightened.
Now there's one thing I don't understand.
*One* thing?
At the start of the evening, Yvette was here, by herself, waiting to offer you all a glass of champagne. I was in the hall.
[beat]
I know because I was there.
Wadsworth, am I right in thinking there's nobody else in this house?
Um... no.
Then there is someone else in this house?
Sorry, I said "no" meaning "yes."
"No" meaning "yes?" Look, I want a straight answer, is there someone else, or isn't there, yes, or no?
No.
No there is, or no there isn't?
Yes.

[shatters glass]
PLEASE!
You see? Like the Mounties, we always get our man.
Mrs. Peacock was a man?
[Colonel Mustard slaps Mr. Green, who turns to get slapped by Wadsworth]
And what was your role in all this?
I was a victim, too. At least my wife was. She had friends who were
[on the verge of tears]
Socialists.
[all gasp, Mrs. Peacock is the loudest]

[starts to cry]
Well, we all make mistakes.
[Mrs. White approaches Wadsworth and hands him a handkerchief]

But, Mr. Boddy threatened to give my wife's name to the House Un-American Activities Committee unless she named them. She refused, and so he blackmailed her. We had no money, and the price of his silence was that we worked for him for nothing. We were slaves. Well, to make a long story short...
Too late.
Communism was just a red herring.

[shouting]
That's what we're trying to find out! We're trying to find out *who* killed him, and *where*, and with *what*!
There's no need to shout!

[shouting louder]
I'm not shouting!
[Guests stare at him pointedly]

[shouting]
All right, I am! I'm shouting, I'm shouting, I'm shout...
[candlestick falls from above and hits him on the head]

[after Mrs. Peacock swears that the reason she's being blackmailed is a vicious lie]
Well, I am willing to believe you. I, too, am being blackmailed for something I didn't do.
Me too.
And me.
Not me.

[surprised]
You're *not* being blackmailed?
Oh, I'm being blackmailed all right, but I did what I'm being blackmailed for.
What did you do?
Well, to be perfectly frank, I run a specialized hotel and a telephone service which provides gentlemen with the company of a young lady, for a short while.
Oh yeah?
[pulls out pen and a pad of paper]
What's the phone number?
Uh, can I come in and use your phone?
Of course you may, sir! You may use the one in the, um... no. Uh, you could use the one in the stud... no. Uh, uh, would you be kind enough to wait in the, um, in-in the, um, uh library?
"Ours is not to reason why, ours is but to do and die."
Die?
Merely quoting, sir, from Alfred, Lord Tennyson.
Hm, I prefer Kipling, myself. "The female of the species is more deadly than the male." You like Kipling, Miss Scarlet?
[offers her a tray]

[takes food off the tray]
Sure, I'll eat anything.

[after Mr. Green shoots Wadsworth]
Are you a cop?
No, I'm a plant.
A plant? I thought men like you were usually called a fruit.
Very funny. FBI. That phone call from J. Edgar Hoover was for me.
[opens the door]
Told you I didn't do it!
...and to make a long story short...
Too late!

[listening to caller on phone]
Ah, would you hold on, please?
[Walks over to locked door, rattling the knob and banging on door]
Let me outta here! Let me outta here! You have no right to shut me in! I'll book you for false arrest, and wrongful imprisonment, and obstructing an officer in the course of his duty... and MURDER!

[Wadsworth opens the door, feigning innocence, while other guests gather around]
What do you mean... murder?
I just said it so you would open the door.
[other guests laugh]
What's going on around here? And why would you lock me in? And why are you receiving phone calls from J. Edgar Hoover?
J. Edgar Hoover?
That's right! The head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation!
Why is J. Edgar Hoover on your phone?
I don't know, he's on everybody else's, why shouldn't he be on mine?
But it is dark upstairs and I am frightened of the dark. Will anyone go with me?
I will!
I will!
No, thank you.

Well, someone's got to break the ice, and it might as well be me. I mean, I'm used to being a hostess, it's part of my husband's work. And it's always difficult when a group of new friends meet together for the first time, to get acquainted. So I'm perfectly prepared to start the ball rolling. I mean, I-I have absolutely no idea what we're doing here. Or what I'm doing here, or what this place is about, but I am determined to enjoy myself. And I'm very intrigued, and, oh my, this soup's delicious, isn't it?

[after learning who killed Mr. Boddy, the motorist, the cook, the cop, and Yvette]
So it must've been Mr. Green who shot the singing telegram!
I didn't do it!
Well, there's nobody else left.
But I didn't do it! The gun is missing! Whoever's got the gun shot the girl!

[extracts his gun]
I shot her.
Mr. Boddy. Dead... Again!
This is war, Peacock. Casualties are inevitable. You can not make an omelet without breaking eggs, every cook will tell you that.
But look what happened to the cook!
Is there gonna be a cover up?
Isn't that in the public interest? What could be gained by exposure?
But is the FBI in the habit of cleaning up after a multiple murder?
Yes. Why do you think it's run by a man called Hoover?
Three murders?
Six altogether.
This is getting serious.

I hardly think it will enhance your reputation at the U.N. Professor Plum, if it's revealed that you have been implicated not only in adultery with one of your patients, but in her death and the deaths of five other people.
You don't know what kind of people they have at the U.N., I might go up in their estimation.
What about that motorist? What kind of information did he have?
He was my driver during the war.
And what was he holding over you?
He knew that I was a war profiteer. I stole essential Air Force radio parts, and I sold them on the black market. That is how I made all my money. But that does not make me a murderer!
Well, a lot of our airmen died, because their radios didn't work.

[gets up in front of everyone]
I have something to say. I'm not going to wait for Wadsworth here to unmask me. I work for the State Department, and I'm a homosexual.
[pause]
I feel no personal shame or guilt about this, but I must keep it a secret, or I will lose my job on security grounds.
[pause]
Thank you.
What is your top-secret job, Colonel?
I can tell you. He's working on the secret of the next fusion bomb.
How did you know that?
Can you keep a secret?
Yes...
So can I.
Good evening. Have you ever given any thought to the kingdom of heaven?
What?
Repent. The kingdom of heaven *is* at hand.
You ain't just whistlin' Dixie.
Armageddon is almost upon us.
I got news for you - it's already here.
Go away.
But your souls are in danger.
Our lives our in danger, you beatnik.
[Plum and White are looking at the photographic negatives]
Oh my! Nobody can get into THAT position.
Sure they can. Let me show you.
[lays her down on the couch and gets on top of her]
Get off me!
You've got blood on your hands.
I DIDN'T DO IT!
Uh, is there a little girl's room in the hall?
Oui oui, Madame.
[points]
No, I just wanna powder my nose.

you're all being blackmailed. For some considerable time, all of you have been paying what you can afford, and in some cases more than you can afford, to someone who threatens to expose you. And none of you know who's blackmailing you. Do you?

[nervously smoking]
Oh, please! I've never heard anything so ridiculous. I mean, nobody could blackmail me. My life is an open book. I've never done anything wrong.

[short pause]
Anybody else wish to deny it?

[pointing to Mrs. Peacock's drink]
Maybe he was poisoned!
[Mrs. Peacock immediately drops her glass full of brandy and starts screaming]

[trying to get her to the couch]
Mrs. Peacock, please. Mrs. Peacock, it's alright. It's alright. We don't know anything. Sit-sit down, sit down, Mrs.-
[slaps her; everybody stares]
Well, I had to stop her from screaming!
And monkey's brains, though popular in Cantonese cuisine, are not often to be found in Washington D.C.
Is that what we ate?
[makes a retching sound]
I suggest we take the cook's body into the study.
Why?
I'm the butler, I like to keep the kitchen tidy.
[doorbell rings during 'events of the evening']
Oh, who ever it is, they gotta go away or they'll be killed.
[Wadsworth has just greeted Mr. Green at the door]

[to the dogs]
Sit!
[Mr. Green quickly and nervously sits down on a bench]
No, not you, sir.

[after Mrs. White knees Mr. Boddy in the crotch]
Was that necessary, Mrs. White?
Is this place for you?
Indeed no, sir. I'm merely a humble butler.
What exactly do you do?
I buttle, sir.
Which means what?
The butler is head of the kitchen and dining room. I keep everything tidy.
So, what do you do in Washington D.C., Mr. Green? Come on! What do you do? I mean, how are we to get acquainted if we don't say anything about ourselves.
Perhaps he doesn't wanna get acquainted with you.
Well, I'm sure I don't know. But if I wasn't trying to keep the conversation going, then we would just be sitting here in an embarrassed silence.
Are you afraid of silence, Mrs. Peacock?
Yes-What? No! Why?
Well, it just seems to me that you are. You seem to suffer from what we call "Pressure of Speech".
"We"? Who's we? Are you a shrink?
I do know a little bit about psychological medicine, yes.
What are you all staring at?
Nothing.
Well who's there?
Nobody.
What do you mean?
Nobody. No body, that's what we mean. Mr. Boddy's body, it's gone.
Maybe he wasn't dead.
He was!
We should've made sure.
How?
[muttering]
By cutting his head off, I suppose.
That was uncalled for!
You're Mr. Boddy!
[Wadsworth laughs evilly]
Wait a minute. So who did I kill?
My butler.
Oh, shucks.
He was expendable like all of you. I'm grateful to you all for disposing of my network of spies and informers. Saved me a lot of trouble. Now there's no evidence against me.
Where is it?
What? The body?
The phone. What body?
There's no body. Nobody. There's-there's nobody in the study.

[after Mr. Boddy hands out his party gifts]
I enjoy getting presents from strange men.
Mr. Boddy threatened to send those pictures to my dear old mother, the shock would've killed her.
Oh, that would've been quite an achievement, since you told us that she's dead already.
[to Wadsworth]
So, he had the motive.
You *all* had a motive.
Well, one of us must have killed him!
How did you get in?
The door was locked!
It's a great trick!
Who would wanna kill the cook?
Dinner wasn't that bad.
How can you make jokes at a time like this?
It's my defense mechanism.
Some defense. If I was the killer, I would kill you next.
Oh?
[Everyone looks at Colonel Mustard]
I said, "if". *If*!

In your hands, you each have a lethal weapon. If you denounce me to the police, you will also be exposed and humiliated. I'll see to that in court. But, if one of you kills Wadsworth now, no one but the seven of us will ever know. He has the key to the front door, which he said would only be opened over his dead body. I suggest we take him up on that offer. The only way to avoid finding yourselves on the front pages is for one of you to kill Wadsworth. NOW.
[Mr. Boddy has disappeared after being killed]
He couldn't have been dead.
He was. At least I thought he was, but what difference does it make now?
Makes quite a difference to him.

[Doorbell rings, the door is opened to reveal a singing Telegram girl]
Da da da da da da! I, am, your singing telegram...!
[Unseen figure shoots her, she falls to the ground, and the front door is slammed shut]

[Smashes glass on fireplace]
PLEASE! Don't you think we should get that man out of the house before he finds out what's been going on here!
[Drops thre rest of the glass with a crash]
Yeah!
How can we throw him outside in this weather?
If we let him stay in the house, he may get suspicious!
If we throw him out, he may get even more suspicious!
If I were him, I'd be suspicious already!

[hysterical]
Oh, who cares? That guy doesn't matter! Let him stay locked up for another half an hour. The police will be here by then... and there are two dead bodies in the study!
Shhhhhhhhhhh!

[fanning herself]
Oh, my God.
She's going to faint.
Somebody catch her!
[Wadsworth goes behind Mrs. Peacock and encircles her with his arms]
I'll catch you. Fall into my arms.
[Mrs. Peacock falls straight through Wadsworth's arms and onto the floor]
Sorry.
Yvette, could you attend to the Colonel and give him anything he requires? Within reason, that is.
So, what does your husband do?

[quickly]
Nothing!
Nothing?
Well, he just lies around on his back all day.
Sounds like hard work to me.
[Wadsworth reveals a secret passage from the study to the kitchen]
How did you know?
This house belongs to a friend of mine. I've known all along.
So you could be the murderer.
Don't be ridiculous. If I was the murderer, why would I reveal to you how I did it?
[a scream is heard in the locked billiard room]
It must be the murderer.
Why would *he* scream?
[Cop sniffs the motorist, who is dead]
This man's drunk. Dead drunk.
Dead right!

[to the motorist]
You're not gonna drive home, are you?
He won't be driving home, officer, I promise you that!
No.
Somebody will give him a lift, huh?
Oh, we'll- we'll- we'll get him a car!
A long black car!

[lightly jabbing him in the stomach]
A limousine!

[trying to find Mrs. White in the dark after hearing her scream]
I'm coming! I'm just trying to find the door. Coming.
[finds what seems to be a doorknob]
What's this? Another door?
[turns "doorknob", gets blasted with water from a shower]

[looks in an envelope]
What's this, Wadsworth?
I'm afraid those are the negatives to which Colonel Mustard earlier referred.
Oh my God!
Were you planning to blackmail him, Wadsworth?
Certainly not! I detained them for the colonel and I was going to give them back as soon as Mr. Boddy was unmasked.
Mm, very pretty! Would you like to see these, Yvette, they might shock you.
No, merci. I am a lady.
Oh, how do you know what kind of pictures they are if you're such a lay-dee?
What sort of pictures are they?
They are *my* pictures and I'd like them back, please!
No, I'm afraid there's something in them that concerns me, too.
Let me see.

[gasps]
Oh no, nobody can get into that position.
Sure they can. Let me show you.
[tries to do the position]
Get off me!
Well, I'm gonna start while it's still hot.
Oh, now, shouldn't we wait for the other guest?
I will keep something warm for him.
What did you have in mind, dear?
Why should the police come? Nobody's called them.
You mean... oh my God, of course!
I have nothing to hide! I didn't do it!

[both insistent]
Well, there is still some confusion as to whether or not there is anybody else in this house!
I told you, there isn't.
There isn't any confusion, or there isn't anybody else?
Either! Or both.
Just give me a clear answer!
Certainly!
[clears throat]
What was the question?

[shouting]
Is there anybody else in this house?

[shouting]
No!
So what do you do, Professor?
I work for UNO, the United Nations Organization.
Another politician. Jesus!
No, I work for a branch of UNO. W.H.O., the World Health Organization.
Well, one of us did. We all had the opportunity, we all had a motive.
Great. We'll all go to the chair.
...and we all revealed that you had a letter and you had a letter and you had a letter and...
Get on with it!
Miss Scarlet seized the opportunity, and under cover of darkness, got to the library, where she hit the cop whom she'd been bribing on the head with the lead pipe. True or false?

[impressed]
True! Who are you, Perry Mason?
Well, where is he?
[Miss Scarlet screams as the freezer door opens and Wadsworth falls out. Mr. Green catches Wadsworth, then drops him disgustedly]

[yelling]
Will you stop that?
No.
Oh, you're a doctor?
I am, but I don't practice.
Practice makes perfect. Ha! I think most men need a little practice, don't you Mrs. Peacock?
Do come in, Madam. You are expected.
Do you know who I am?
Only that you are to be known as Mrs. White.
Yes. It said so in the letter. But why?

[dropped a spoon, spilling soup onto Miss Scarlet]
I'm sorry. I'm afraid I'm a little bit accident-prone.
[starts to wipe soup off Miss Scarlet]

[raises her hands, making him stop]
Ah, watch it!

[next to Miss Scarlet in the rain, with backs to the door]
What a godforsaken place!
[gropes her backside; she tries to brush his hand off]

[opens door suddenly and sees this]
Professor Plum, and Miss Scarlet, I didn't realize you were acquainted.
We weren't.
You recognized Yvette, didn't you? Don't deny it!
What do you mean, "Don't deny it"? I'm not denying anything!
Another denial!
Thhbbtt!
[sticks her tongue out at Wadsworth]
But this is ridiculous. If he were such a patriotic American, why didn't he just report us to the authorities?
He decided to put his information to good use and make a little money out of it. What could be more American than that?

[Professor Plum and Mrs. Peacock have drawn cut matches of the same length, pairing them together]
It's you and me, honeybunch.

[referring to Mr. Boddy]
Well, he's certainly dead now. Why would anyone want to kill him twice?
It seems so unnecessary.
Well, it's what we call "overkill."
It's what we call "psychotic."
What room's this?
Search me.
All right.
[he starts to frisk her]
Get your mitts off me.
What's going on in those two rooms?
Uhh... which two rooms?
*Those* two rooms.
Ohhh, those two rooms.
Yes.
Ahh... well. Officer! I don't think you should go in there.
Why not?
Uhh... Because it's all too shocking!
We didn't hear the cook scream... because Mrs. Peacock was screaming about the poisoned brandy.
When I said that I was Mr. Boddy's butler, this was both true and misleading. I was once his butler. But it was not his untimely death this evening that brought my employment with him to an end.
When did it come to an end?

When my wife decided to end her life. She, too, was being blackmailed by this odious man who now lies dead before us. He hated my wife for the same reason that he hated all of you. He believed that you were all thoroughly un-American.
[the table which Mr. Green is leaning against breaks, causing a great crashing sound]
[Awkwardly]
Sorry.
For some reason, he felt it was inappropriate for a senator to have a corrupt wife; for a doctor to take advantage of his patients; for a wife to emasculate her husband; and, and... so forth.
But, this is ridiculous; if he was such a patriotic American, why didn't he just report us to the authorities?
He decided to put his information to good use, and make a little money out of it. What could be more American than that?
And what was your role in all of this?
I was a victim, too. At least, my wife was. She had friends who were
[pause, beginning to cry]
socialists.
[the guests react, Mrs. Peacock loudly gasping]
Well,
[pausing]
we all make mistakes.
[Mrs. White comforts him with her handkerchief]

But Mr. Boddy threatened to give my wife's name to the House Un-American Activities Committee unless she named them. She refused. And so he blackmailed her. We had no money. And the price of his silence was that we work for him for nothing. We were slaves.
You all seem to be very anxious about something.
It's the chandelier. It fell down, almost killed us.
Sorry, didn't mean to frighten you.
You're a bit late for that! I hate it when he does that.
Ahhh!

[nasally]
No.

[imitating him]
No?
No.
Picked up the dagger, ran down the hall, and stabbed the cook!
Take your hands off me! I'm a senator's wife!
[from trailer]
Why are you screaming?
Because I'm frightened!
Of what?
Screaming!
This is one of my favorite recipes.
I know, Madam.
[Making fun of Mr. Green]
Well, I had to stop her screaming.
Go on. I'll be right behind you.
That's why I'm nervous.

[gesturing to another place setting at the dinner table]
So, is this for our host?
No, sir, for the seventh guest, Mr Boddy.
I thought Mr. Boddy was our host.
So did I.
So, who is our host Mr. Wadsworth?
[Wadsworth only smiles in response]
[first lines]
Is everything ready?
Oui, Monsieur.
You have your, um, instructions.
Is everything all right, Mrs. Ho?
You say you are used to being a hostess as part of your husband's work?
Yes, it's an integral part of your life when you are the wife of a... Oh, but then I forgot, we're not supposed to say who we really are, though, heavens to Betsy, I don't know why.
Don't you?
I know who you are.
Aren't you gonna tell us?
How do you know who I am?
I work in Washington, too.
Washington? So you're a politician's wife?
Yes, I-I am.
Well, come on then, who's your husband?
You lockin' me in? I'll take the key.
Over my dead body, sir.
I didn't do it!
Well, one of us did. We all had an opportunity. We all had a motive.
[Mr. Green shoots Wadsworth]
Good shot, Green!
[he slowly slumps to the floor, checks his chest, revealing a bloody palm]
And *very* good.
[he dies]

[to the furnace]
Argh. Don't you touch me!

[after everyone introduces themselves]
Well, that just leaves Mr. Boddy.
What's your little secret?
His secret? Oh, haven't you guessed? He's the one who's blackmailing you.
Why should the police come? Nobody's called them.
Why?
To create confusion.
It worked!

[referring to negatives of Colonel Mustard's private photos]
Nobody can get into that position.
Sure they can. Let me show you.
[attempts the sexual position with Mrs. White]
Get off me!

[Wadsworth has just returned inside after throwing the key to the cupboard away]
Well, what now?
Wadsworth, let me out.
No.
Why not?
We've gotta know who did it. We're all in this together now.
If you leave, I'll say that you killed them both.
Me too.
Me too.
Me too.

[Suddenly becoming mysteriously flirtatious]
Oh, Wadsworth, I'll make you sorry you ever started this.
[She grabs hold of Wadsworth's tie, rubbing his chest]
